Award.AwardTitle: Vectorial Folding of Large, Multidomain Proteins

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Title: Vectorial Folding of Large, Multidomain Proteins

Proteins are biological molecules composed of amino acid building blocks connected into polymer-like chains. They are critically important in life processes by providing structural elements to cells and by performing many active cellular functions, for example as oxygen carriers in red blood cells, by generating contractile forces in muscles and by supporting the immune system because they are able to recognize and bind foreign molecules. Their ability to perform their cellular functions is dependent upon proteins folding into the appropriate structure. When proteins misfold, not only do they loose function but they can also cause diseases such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease. To date, significant progress has been made toward understanding of how small (~100 amino acids), model proteins acquire their three-dimensional structures, however, very little is known about folding mechanisms of large, complex, multi-domain proteins that dominate all forms of life. The long-term objective of this project is to advance understanding of the folding mechanisms of large, complex, multi-domain proteins by using a combination of experimental and computational techniques. This project will provide an exciting interdisciplinary education and research opportunity for 3 graduate and 6 undergraduate students. This project also combines several experimental disciplines and it will provide a rich learning experience for all people involved, junior and senior researchers alike. Outreach activities will involve K12 students and their teachers.

In this project the mechanism of folding of large, complex, multi-domain proteins will be examines using a combination of experimental and computational techniques. The hypothesis that large multi-domain proteins fold sequentially under vectorial constraint conditions to avoid misfolding, and not in a two-state-fashion typical of small proteins, will be examined. Single-molecule protein folding data will be acquired by combining DNA and protein engineering with Atomic Force Microscopy-based and optical trap-based single-molecule force spectroscopy (AFM-SMFS, OT-SMFS) measurements. Computational methods such as Steered Molecular Dynamics (SMD) will be performed in parallel to experimental measurements and aid in interpreting data. Multi-domain proteins present a unique problem for interpreting AFM-SMFS and OT-SMFS data: the domain that gives rise to a signal must be identified out of the multiple domains in the protein. To circumvent this issue, novel polypeptide-based 'folding probes' such as antiparallel coiled-coils will be developed that can be inserted into large proteins at critical positions to report on the folding status of the surrounding structure when interrogated by SMFS. These studies will examine mechanical folding of a number of large proteins with increasing size and structural complexity that supports their important biological functions such as ATP synthesis or DNA replication. The research will advance the knowledge about one of the most fundamental unsolved problems in biology; mechanisms allowing long amino acid chains to fold into complex, multidomain structures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Proteins are polymeric molecules composed of amino acids that, depending on the specific amino acid sequence, form unique 3D structures that are critical for many enzymatic, mechanical and communicational/recognitional functions within living cells and their structural or chemical breakdown may result in severe diseases. Proteins’ structures and functions have been intensively studied for over 50 years and one of the difficult and not fully resolved problems has been related to how proteins create their unique structures. Even though significant progress has been made in addressing this “protein folding” problem for small proteins typically composed of less than 100 amino acids, there is a large gap in understanding of how large proteins composed of many structurally similar or diverse domains with as many as 500-1000 amino acids fold and retain their 3D functional structures. However, it is very important to understand the behavior of large proteins as their fraction in living cells is much larger as compared to small proteins and misfolding of these proteins causes cellular stresses.

 

The long-term objective of this project has been to advance understanding of the folding mechanism of large, complex, multidomain proteins by: 

a)      studying their unfolding and refolding behavior at a single molecule level under conditions that minimize protein aggregation, which makes many bulk experiments impossible

b)      examining their unfolding and refolding behaviors using Atomic Force Spectroscopy techniques and computational modeling that provide folding conditions similar to those experienced by protein molecules in living cells when they are synthesized from amino acids

c)      examining the hypothesis that large multidomain proteins do not unfold and refold in a two-state fashion typical of small proteins, but fold sequentially to reduce the odds of misfolding 

 

The activities within this Project confirmed the main hypothesis of this research regarding complex folding behaviors of large multidomain proteins and resulted in several new significant observations such as:

a)     large multi-domain proteins generally do not follow a simple two-state (folded/unfolded) behavior typical of small single-domain proteins, but rather unfold and fold stepwise, forming several independently folding nuclei within core domains

b)     as illustrated by the study of a model multidomain protein luciferase, folding pathways may originate in different domains, but when they start in the N terminal segments (which is consistent with how proteins are synthesized in the cell) the process is most likely to succeed in producing the correct structure of the whole protein, while folding pathways that originate elsewhere along the protein chain, may more frequently lead to incorrect (misfolded) structures

c)     AFM-based mechanical unfolding and refolding measurements of various fragments of multidomain proteins combined with computational modeling may capture intermediate folding structures of large proteins, which are otherwise difficult to characterize.

d)     The unfolding/refolding behavior of multidomain proteins with similarly folded domains cannot be deduced by separately analyzing these domains. This has been illustrated by examining phosphoglycerate kinase (PGK), an important enzyme that participates in the synthesis of ATP, which cells use as energy source. Such multidomain proteins display complex unfolding behavior in that they stochastically probe several distinct pathways in which the unfolding process may start at any domain and the mechanical behavior of a given domain in the protein may be different from the behavior of the isolated domain, so the behavior of the complete protein cannot be simply deduced by analyzing its components.

e)     protein domains in multidomain proteins, such as beta-gamma-crystallin may be selectively stabilized by external agents such as ubiquitous calcium ions and in the absence of these ions may tend to destabilize, which may adversely affect their biological functions. This behavior may be at the onset of deleterious processes such as those that lead to protein misfolding aggregation and subsequent developments of tumors or cataracts

The results of this Project were presented at 8 scientific conferences and published in 2 book chapters and 9 peer-reviewed journal publications. One article is currently under review and two more manuscripts are nearing submission for publication.

Throughout its duration, the Project trained 3 post-doctoral researchers, 6 PhD students 2 Master students and 3 undergraduate students. Thus, the Project contributed to building a new cadre of young researchers interested in exploring the molecular foundations of biophysical processes underlying protein folding, structure and function and equipped with cutting-edge tools to carry out such studies.

 

In addition to forwarding the primary discipline, the project significantly contributed to the development of research technology within molecular biophysics by generating new molecular probes and handles for force spectroscopy measurements that have been made available to other researchers through Addgene, the nonprofit plasmid repository. Also, the Project developed a Visual Protocol through the publication in the Journal of Visual Experiments that can be followed by new and experienced researchers to study many other proteins using AFM-based force-spectroscopy techniques.
